title: How to Clean a Spa Filter

steps.title: Locate your filter cartridge.
steps.content: Locate your filter cartridge. Oftentimes, you can partially see the filter from the inside of the spa system. It is most often located inside of a canister, cradle, or lid. If you do not see such a compartment, check your owner's manual to locate the filter.

steps.title: Turn your spa system off before you remove the filter.
steps.content: Turn your spa system off before you remove the filter. As the parts of spa systems work together to achieve filtration, you should not run the spa without a filter cartridge present.

steps.title: Turn the filter counterclockwise.
steps.content: Turn the filter counterclockwise. Move slowly and gently to prevent damage. As you rotate, examine the filter for bottom threads that may also need to be unscrewed. If this loosens the filter, pull it up and out of the compartment. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Consult your owner's manual.
steps.content: Consult your owner's manual. While many styles of cartridge filters are easily removed with a counterclockwise turn, not all are removed so simply. If a gentle twist does not loosen your filter, allow your owner's manual to walk you through the removal process.

steps.title: Examine the filter for damage.
steps.content: Examine the filter for damage. If you see rips, tears, or feel as though the center core element is loose, do not move forward with cleaning the filter. Be sure to replace damaged filters to avoid damaging other spa elements, such as jet lines, that may become prone to debris build-up. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Use a filter cleaning wand to rinse out your spa filter.
steps.content: Use a filter cleaning wand to rinse out your spa filter. Look for a cleaning wand that attaches to your garden hose and comes equipped with soft comb-like teeth. Hold the nozzle at a 45 degree angle and use the comb to gently open and rinse debris from the pleats of the spa filter.

steps.title: Add a drop of enzyme-based products to the water.
steps.content: Add a drop of enzyme-based products to the water. Enzymes prevent biofilm—the sticky, tar-like film of bacteria that sometimes grows in pools and spas—by breaking up oils and other contaminants that create conditions for bacteria to grow. [3] X Research source Adding a weekly dose of cleaner directly to the water thus keeps your filter clean by preventing a scummy ring of oils from building around the filter core. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Examine the filter for remaining debris.
steps.content: Examine the filter for remaining debris. Gently part the pleats of the filter and examine for dirt build-up or large debris. Remove and throw away any large pieces of debris.

steps.title: Fill a large plastic bucket with water.
steps.content: Fill a large plastic bucket with water. Typically, five gallons is the amount of water necessary to fully immerse a spa filter. Do not worry about water temperature—hot water cleans more rapidly, but cold water will clean the filter just as well. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Mix in mild cleanser.
steps.content: Mix in mild cleanser. Follow the instructions on your brand of spa filter cleanser to determine how much should be added per gallon of water. [6] X Research source Do not use anything other than filter cleanser to clean your filter. Some people choose to use bleach or detergent to clean filters, but these harsh chemicals may actually damage filters or trigger issues with water chemistry. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Repeat the weekly cleaning steps.
steps.content: Repeat the weekly cleaning steps. Before you treat the spa filter with cleanser, be sure to protect your spa by turning it off and visually inspecting your filter for damage. Spray with your hose-head cleaning wand to remove any lingering debris. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Soak the filter.
steps.content: Soak the filter. If you used hot water, soak for roughly an hour. If you filled your bucket with cold water, allow the filter to soak overnight. [9] X Research source Remember to keep your pool off while your filter is soaking.

steps.title: Rinse the filter with a cleaning wand.
steps.content: Rinse the filter with a cleaning wand. After it has soaked, be sure to thoroughly rinse it to remove chemicals or remaining debris. Remember to hold the cleaning wand at a 45 degree angle to prevent dirt from being driven into the core. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Clean the water.
steps.content: Clean the water. Follow the sanitation instructions outlined in your spa's owner manual by adding cleansing chemicals directly into the water. Improper cleaning and water chemistry may lead to the growth of algae and bacteria that can make you sick. Excess residue may damage the components of your spa system and shorten the life of your filter.

steps.title: Be patient.
steps.content: Be patient. Taking your time to carefully clean a cartridge will ensure that you remove as much debris as possible, which will in turn lengthen the life of your filter. Plus, providing a thorough cleaning this time will make the next round of cleaning even easier. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Make sure the filter is white.
steps.content: Make sure the filter is white. If you are putting back a recently cleaned filter, it should be white and free of debris. If it is tinted black or coated in a slimy residue, do not put in back in your spa system. [12] X Research source A new filter should be installed every one to three years, so you will likely encounter an unusable filter at some point. It is a good idea to keep an extra filter in storage for when replacement becomes necessary.

steps.title: Slide the filter into place.
steps.content: Slide the filter into place. Simply reverse the removal process to replace a filter. For most filters, sliding it back into its compartment will require twisting it to the right.

steps.title: Start up your hot tub.
steps.content: Start up your hot tub. Once the filter has been installed, allow the spa to run for one full cycle before you use it. This will deplete any debris that may have collected while your spa system was not actively filtering the water.
